reading_passages.title: About Indian Early Civilizations, Empires, and World Religions
reading_passages.text: Lesson 1 Big Idea Indian civilization first developed along the Indus River. Main Ideas •Located on the Indus River, the Harappan civilization also had contact with people far from India.
reading_passages.main_idea: Lesson 1 Big Idea Indian civilization first developed along the Indus River.
supporting_details: Main Ideas •Located on the Indus River, the Harappan civilization also had contact with people far from India.

reading_passages.title: About Indian Early Civilizations, Empires, and World Religions
reading_passages.text: Lesson 2 Big Idea Hinduism, the largest religion in India, developed out of ancient Indian beliefs and practices. Main Ideas •Hinduism developed out of Brahmanism and influences from other cultures.
reading_passages.main_idea: Lesson 2 Big Idea Hinduism, the largest religion in India, developed out of ancient Indian beliefs and practices.
supporting_details: Main Ideas •Hinduism developed out of Brahmanism and influences from other cultures.

reading_passages.title: About Indian Early Civilizations, Empires, and World Religions
reading_passages.text: Essential Question Preview What role did religion play in the development of Indian civilizations and empires? Have students consider the Essential Question and capture their initial responses. Explore the Essential Question •Point out the similarities and differences in the basic beliefs of Hinduism, Buddhism, Jainism, and Sikhism. Tell students that all three religions developed in the same part of the world.
reading_passages.main_idea: Essential Question Preview What role did religion play in the development of Indian civilizations and empires?
supporting_details: Have students consider the Essential Question and capture their initial responses.
Explore the Essential Question •Point out the similarities and differences in the basic beliefs of Hinduism, Buddhism, Jainism, and Sikhism.
Tell students that all three religions developed in the same part of the world.

scientific_phenomena.title: Indian Early Civilizations, Empires, and World Religions Landform
scientific_phenomena.description: For example, if you look at a physical map of India, you can see what landforms are in a region. You can then look at a population map to see how many people live in that region. From this comparison, you can conclude how the region’s landforms affect its population distribution.

scientific_phenomena.description: The Khyber Pass Various invaders have found their way from central Asia through the mountains into India by means of the Khyber Pass. It is a narrow passage about 30 miles (48.

scientific_phenomena.title: Indian Early Civilizations, Empires, and World Religions Mountain
scientific_phenomena.description: Most historians and archaeologists believe that the Aryans crossed into India through mountain passes in the northwest. Others think the Aryans might have been native to the subcontinent. Over many centuries, they spread east and south into central India.

scientific_phenomena.title: Indian Early Civilizations, Empires, and World Religions Water
scientific_phenomena.description: The fertile land and water from the river allowed them to develop a farming economy. They used irrigation canals to bring water from the Indus and other rivers to their fields to help their crops grow. While they did grow plants and keep animals for food, wild species contin- ued to be important to their civilization and growth.
observation_prompts: What features of water can you identify in Indian Early Civilizations, Empires, and World Religions?

What patterns do you notice about water in Indian Early Civilizations, Empires, and World Religions?

scientific_phenomena.title: Indian Early Civilizations, Empires, and World Religions Forest
scientific_phenomena.description: In fact, the rituals were so secret that they had to be done in the forest, far from other people. The final group of Vedic texts are the Upanishads ( oo-PAHN-ee-shads), most of which were written by about 600 BC. These w ritings are religious students’ and teachers’ reflections on the Vedas.

writing_prompts: Using information from the passage and your own knowledge, write an informative paragraph about Indian Early Civilizations, Empires, and World Religions. Include at least three vocabulary terms from Part 1.
Describe an important geographic feature of Indian Early Civilizations, Empires, and World Religions and explain its significance to the region.
